abstract.p: Peter DePasquale, Bob Burgess and Sam Gulisano, executives who recently left New York office of FCB Worldwide, are opening Dirty Water in New York, interactive ad agency with 31 employees and billings estimated at $37.5 million (Advertising column) (S)

block.p: Three executives who recently left the New York office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, are opening Dirty Water in New York, an interactive agency with 31 employees and billings estimated at $37.5 million.

The executives are: Peter DePasquale, 45, chief executive, who had been senior vice president and group management director at FCB New York; Bob Burgess, 47, chief financial officer, who had held the same post at FCB New York; and Sam Gulisano, 50, chief creative officer, who had been co-creative director at FCB New York.

Three executives who recently left the New York office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, are opening Dirty Water in New York, an interactive agency with 31 employees and billings estimated at $37.5 million.

The executives are: Peter DePasquale, 45, chief executive, who had been senior vice president and group management director at FCB New York; Bob Burgess, 47, chief financial officer, who had held the same post at FCB New York; and Sam Gulisano, 50, chief creative officer, who had been co-creative director at FCB New York.

Initial clients of Dirty Water include FlightTime.com in Waltham, Mass., an online executive jet charter company; HowStuffWorks.com in Raleigh, N.C., a question-and-answer Web site; and SharkTank.com in Waltham, a legal services reference Web site. Some Dirty Water clients are companies that are financed by the venture capital funds that provided the money to help open Dirty Water: BancBoston Ventures, the venture capital arm of FleetBoston Financial, and Southeast Interactive Technology Funds.
